summary: Lee Harvey Oswald is the central figure in the JFK assassination, identified as the assassin by the Warren Commission. The documents reveal investigations into his background, activities, and potential connections to various organizations and individuals, including the CIA, KGB, Fair Play for Cuba Committee, and figures in the Soviet and Cuban embassies. His time in the Soviet Union, his visits to the Soviet and Cuban embassies in Mexico City, and his interactions with various individuals before the assassination are scrutinized. The documents also explore allegations of his potential involvement with intelligence agencies and the possibility of a broader conspiracy. There are repeated investigations into whether the CIA had contact with Oswald, especially after his return from the Soviet Union, and into his activities in Mexico City leading up to the assassination. The documents also reveal efforts to access KGB files on Oswald and the challenges in obtaining them.
significance: Lee Harvey Oswald's significance lies in his role as the alleged assassin of President John F. Kennedy. The documents reflect the extensive investigations and inquiries into his life, motives, and potential connections to intelligence agencies and foreign governments, all aimed at understanding the circumstances surrounding the assassination and determining whether he acted alone or as part of a larger conspiracy.
